Posts.Content: [QUOTE=<link deleted>[/QUOTE] Sorry! I didn't know links were prohibited. You can do an Internet search of RXSleeve though. First thing on the site asks if you are 18 and over, don't worry it's not a porn site! It looks like a good option for some. I originally was going to post it on the thread about the woman with a high sex drive but its locked. Sorry again about the link!
Posts.Title: Penis sleeve for ED

Posts.Content: I've been skimming through the threads and started wondering if there were products out there that would act as a sleeve for men with ED and it turns out there is. Has anyone heard of the RXSleeve? Not sure how much pleasure it would give the men but it might simulate some normalcy for couples. <link deleted>
Posts.Title: Penis sleeve for ED

Posts.Content: Highlander, thank you for the information! Worried daughter2, I believe he was having some symptoms, ED, intermittent urine flow obstruction and his PSA had doubled from one test to the next (I think they were a few years apart) and the doctor felt something when he did the exam.
Posts.Title: Dad just diagnosed

Posts.Content: My dad is 67 and was given a diagnosis of prostate cancer yesterday. He just received his lab results today but has not talked to or seen his physician. Can you tell me a little about his results. I've been reading through the posts on here and it looks like 7 is middle of the road. What would be the common next steps? A MRI? Does the fact that it says negative perineural invasion mean it has stayed contained in the prostate? Thanks in advance. PSA was 3.7 I believe Gleason left side 7 (4+3) involving 7/9 cores and involving 75% of tissue. -Prostatic Adenocarcinoma Negative for perineural invasion Gleason right side 7 (4+3) involving 1/11 cores and involving less than 10% of tissue - Prostatic Adenocarcinoma Negative for perineural invasion

Posts.Title: Dad just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Kristen, I don't have any advice but just wanted to say that my dads in a similar situation. 67, Gleason 4+3, cancer appears to be confined to the prostate. Only difference, other than a few years, is his is on both sides. One side had a few positive samples the other much more. He is still in the research and plan stage but right now is leaning towards robotic removal and going to The City of Hope for treatment. He too is very concerned about incontinence, as I'm sure anyone would be, but knows the alternative isn't great either. Good luck to your father! It's a strange place to be in as an adult child. I've always seen my dad as this un-breakable man and it is hard to see him faced with something like cancer. He is handling it like he does everything, obsessive research and lots of logic. His first week or so were spent trying to find stable ground again but he is much better now that he's put on his boxing gloves preparing to fight this thing.
Posts.Title: My Dad diagnosed with Prostate Cancer-so many questions-any advice, info, help?
